header: The weather data used in this project is from **"National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)"** from [Google BigQuery](https://console.cloud.google.com/marketplace/details/noaa-public/gsod). Historical daily weather data were queried for each U.S. state location. The wildfire data comes from the same Kaggle dataset mentioned in the previous page.
This page shows the relationship between wildfire incidents and different weather conditions.

month.overview: In general, the months of February to April have the most wildfire incidents, even though the average temperatures during these months are lower. More thorough analysis is needed to understand why this is the case.
month.All: Further observations about the selected state may be displayed if a state is selected from the options above (for some states only).
month.CA: **CA:** There is an obvious correlation between temperatures and wildfire incidents in CA, which is what would have been expected. More wildfires occur during California summer months.
month.TX: **TX:** The months with most wildfires in Texas are January to March, and August. August is the hottest month in Texas, but January to March are relatively colder. More analysis is needed to understand why more wildfires happen during the winter months in Texas.

weather_measures.temp:
The temperature values are the mean temperatures for the day in degrees Fahrenheit. 

 On all fire size classes, more wildfires seem to occur on higher temperatures, and less on lower temperatures. Larger wildfires also tend to happen at higher temperatures than smaller ones, on average.
weather_measures.dew_point:
Dew point is the temperature to which air must be cooled for the water vapor in it to condense into dew or frost. 

 More wildfires seem to occur on slightly higher dew points.
weather_measures.sea_level_pressure:
This shows the sea level atmospheric or barometric pressure in millibars. 

 More and bigger wildfires seem to occur on days with lower pressure.
weather_measures.max_sustained_wind:
This shows the maximum hourly average sustained wind speed value for the day in knots. 

 Faster wind speed seems to cause bigger wildfires.

weather_conditions.fog: As would have been expected, there are less wildfires during more foggy days.
weather_conditions.rain_drizzle:
More and larger wildfires seem to occur more frequently on days with rain or drizzle. 

 Even though it might not be expected that larger wildfires happen more frequently on rainy days, a possible reason for this is because lightning is a major cause of wildfires.
weather_conditions.thunder:
More and larger wildfires seem to occur more frequently on days with thunder. 

 A possible reason for this is because lightning is a major cause of wildfires.
weather_conditions.tornado_funnel_cloud: More and larger wildfires seem to occur more frequently on days with tornadoes or funnel clouds.
